awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Joshua Cape is "Statistical and spectral analysis of multiple networks." The host institution for the fellowship is University of Michigan, and the sponsoring scientist is Elizaveta Levina.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project developed statistical methodology and theory for network-valued, graph-structured data. In particular, this project created new quantitative tools to enable learning from data sets comprising multiple networks. Such data sets are widely encountered throughout the sciences and include, for example, multi-platform social networks of person-person interactions and multi-subject brain networks of voxel-voxel or region-region connectivity. Successfully leveraging these network data enriches our collective understanding of, for example, information flows throughout society as well as structure or function in the human brain.

This project led to the creation of new latent space models and accompanying theoretical performance guarantees for proposed computational algorithms. A focus of this project was multivariate matrix-based methods for analyzing numerical arrays of data representing pairwise interactions between entities. The PI established rigorous statistical justification for the use of low-dimensional eigenvector-based embeddings of multiple network data. The project advances contemporary understanding of how to effectively compare, contrast, and align data summaries when represented as point cloud configurations. Findings from this project have been successfully applied to social media friendship network data and to neuroimaging brain scan network data.

During this project, the PI co-authored and single-authored multiple peer-reviewed research publications. To successfully carry out the proposed work, the PI synthesized concepts from statistics, probability, network analysis, machine learning, and computer science. The PI developed several long-term collaborations with researchers in sociology, economics, biology, and psychiatry which will continue beyond the project period.


Last Modified: 10/27/2023
Modified by: Joshua Cape
